__e: What did I say when I proposed to you, eh?
I said it to my wife 46 years ago when I proposed.
Sunday afternoon, that's when I first proposed.
One day, I asked him to be my boyfriend and he said no.
And... the reason I asked her out in the first place is because she liked him.
I asked her about it years later, and, yeah, that was the signal.
Well, I said, how did the cat get in here?
I asked her once how she gave up everything to be with you.
That was the first moment that I wondered what this moment would feel like.
When he was five years old, I asked my son Steve what he wanted to be when he grew up.
So I asked my mom, and she said he wasn't.
I asked myself, "self, what do you do on the first day of the rest of your life?"
For a minute, I wondered if, once again, I had drunk nine months of my life away.
I didn't know what I was looking at exactly, but I knew something was there, enough that I almost asked right then whether one of those grunts had been you.
And I wondered if a memory is something you have or something you've lost.
Now I haven't asked because I fear I know the answer.
When I asked why... if he said my parents and sister died in a car accident... then I wouldn't have gone and seen them like that.
He told me, "I'm so scared of growing up." I said, "Why?"
And when I asked what was going on, he said that he had... he had made a lot of money in the stock market.
He'd seemed okay since, but when I asked him if he'd like to do anything for his birthday, he told me we should have dinner, just he and I, for an important conversation.
I asked you where this was going and you said you still had things to do with your life.
